content:
The server name depends on the domain of your email address, but all have these same settings:

port 587, STARTTLS security, authentication = normal password, User Name = email address

https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/mobile-email-setup

content: If you click 'account settings' and then 'server settings' there is a box to empty trash on exit. Make sure it is not ticked and trash will remain until you empty it.
creator: davidsk

content:
Come prima cosa ti suggerirei di contattare Aruba ed accertarti che non sia un problema lato server. Il messaggio non è stato possibile inviare il messaggio perché la connessione col server smtps.aruba.it è scaduta in genere indica proprio questo ed è qualcosa che non puoi risolvere da Thunderbird.

Se non ci sono problemi lato server, allora bisognerebbe capire perché la connessione di Thunderbird al server sia così lenta. Spesso a causare questi rallentamenti sono i vari software di sicurezza (antivirus e simili) che si interpongono tra Thunderbird e la Rete.
creator: @next

content:
Grazie per la risposta. Credo che se il problema fosse "lato" aruba, dovrebbero avere lo stesso problema anche alcuni colleghi che utilizzano Thunderbird, invece da loro, con le stesse impostazioni (server posta in uscita), funziona regolarmente. A livello antivirus, è lo stesso che uso da anni (in concomitanza di thunderbird) e non ho mai avuto problemi Symantec Endpoint Protection e SpyHunter (entrambi con regolare licenza). Ho comunque, dopo il tuo consiglio provato a disattivare entrambi, ma non riesco comunque a inviare email (avevo scordato nel primo post di dire, che al contrario le email vengono correttamente ricevute su 2 acconun: Aruba e Gmail). Grazie

DG

content:
I strongly suggest you try rebooting your device in safe mode with networking (that will exclude avast) and try again. While I have experienced some odd issues with folders and mail post V115, a general failure of the software to open any MSF file would indicate an external issue. My guess here would be your antivirus product. For years we have been recommending that folks place a general exclusion on the profile/mail folders because antivirus is prone to messing up when files are opened, updated and closed frequently

You could try deleting all of the MSF files in the profile folder. They only store the information used to populate the lists etc and will automatically regenerate if deleted. But any customized column layouts, sort order etc will be lost in the process.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The body test available to a filter is only the visible text when you read the message, not the actual body text you see when you view the message source. Are you perhaps using source to try and test on a non visible part of the body?
creator: MattAuSupport

creator: sfhowes

content:
Have you tried uninstalling your antivirus instead of Thunderbird?

Thunderbird does not actually differentiate file types. Attachments go through a conversion process when attached converting them to mime encoded text. So in an email, they are all the same (text).

If you are having issues with a specific file type as you appear to be, then the immediate response is to look outside of Thunderbird for something else on your system that has an interest in files, and files of a particular type. The most common and obvious here would be the antivirus. PDF files are a known vector for malware, so most antivirus programs do different things with PDF to other known vector files as they area formatted binary file. So the antivirus is the most logical starting point. It might just be the antivirus is struggling with the file system being slow and it is therefore still scanning when the email goes out.

In a general housekeeping sense, Window does a rather poor job of managing orphaned temp files, so your temp folder might be chock-a-block full of leftover garbage and be the root cause of the A/V struggling. Almost as long as there has been windows, users have complained it gets slower he longer you have it, with some pundits suggesting regular installed of Windows to keep it humming along. One of the things these refreshes do (other than force a lot of software to be reinstalled and in Thunderbird case mail lost) is clear out the temp folder. In this instance, Google threw up a link to Trend Micro for instructions on cleaning up the temp folder. I have linked to them, fundamentally as I don't want to write out the instructions and secondly to offer another point of view as to why you should do this housekeeping. I do not use, not recommend Trend, they just appeared in my first page of search results and their information was factual as far as it went.

It is possible that some other PDF file manager software you have (like adobe) could be causing issues but it is far less likely that an antivirus issue.
creator: MattAuSupport
